newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS - UK's Co-op strikes at predator through court.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - UK's Co-op strikes at predator through court.

text.p: Britain's Co-operative Wholesale Society (CWS) on Friday went on the offensive against a predator that has been stalking it for months, firing off a court order to thwart a hostile bid.

Guernsey-based Lanica Trust admitted it was on the brink of launching a takeover for the 153-year-old funeral parlour to bank mammoth, which sources close to the company said was likely to total 1.0-1.5 billion pounds ($1.6-2.4 billion).

London's High Court had earlier on Friday ordered Lanica, its 31-year-old head Andrew Regan and an offshoot firm called Galileo to disclose any confidential information they have about CWS and explain for what purposes it had been used.
CWS said the court order also applied to Allan Green, one of two CWS executives suspended on Thursday for an alleged breach of trust.
CWS said the suspension of Green, controller of retailing, and David Chambers, chief general manager for buying, marketing and supply chain, "arose from a suspected recent serious breach of trust".
In February, Lanica approached CWS to buy its non-food businesses and speculation has since focused on CWS's profitable Co-operative Bank as one of the main targets.
But in a statement late on Friday Galileo said it wanted to convert the CWS into a limited company and then offer to buy the whole business.
CWS, whose activities range from supermarkets and funeral parlours to insurance and banking, has a complex ownership structure seen until now as a major obstacle to any takeover or break-up attempt.
The group, based in the northern English city of Manchester, is owned by local co-operative societies which in turn have individual members.
Co-op rules mean they are not allowed to make a profit on their holdings, which cost a pound.
Entrepreneur Regan has given little away about his game-plan since the February announcement and shares in Lanica have been suspended since the two sides squared up.
Regan has appointed Hambros Bank to advise on his bid, although the British bank declined any comment. SBC Warburg has been retained by CWS.
Regan's attempt to break-up the CWS is seen as the result of recent poor performances by the multi-billion pound turnover co-operative group, which on Monday reported a fall in 1996 pre-tax profits.
"After the CWS results it was logical that he (Regan) would have to make his move sometime this week," one source told Reuters.
On Monday CWS chief executive Graham Melmoth reiterated the group's stance of not selling any of its businesses to "an asset-stripping middleman".
Melmoth said it was questionable whether Lanica's shares, which have been suspended since February 10, would ever be relisted.
The shares were star performers during 1996 and were suspended at 19.5 pounds each.
In any case, analysts believe that CWS's complicated ownership structure will dog any bid.
"There's no obvious mechanism for a hostile bid for the Co-op to proceed because of its complicated structure," said one, who declined to be named.
But they did not discount the possibility that a way around this obstacle could be found, or that others might not be encouraged to take a close look at CWS's other businesses.
"If Regan gets to the stage where he makes a formal offer, he won't get past first base. But it might flush out some other contenders," the analyst said.
Whatever the outcome, the Co-op will have to take drastic action to improve its performance.
"What it does do is put pressure on the Co-op. It knows it has to do something."
Analysts suggested that this would include cutting the number of individual societies from a current 51 to one or two and consolidating its wide-ranging business interests.
"But the Co-op wants to decide what (to sell) and to whom," one analyst said.
($ = 0.612 British Pounds)
